quizzes.title: History Quiz: Words and Mafia
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, john, di. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Both Adolf Fischer and Douglas Fairbanks Sr. expressed this feeling before they died.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Happiness

questions.question: John Wayne Gacy, the Killer Clown, buried over 30 victims in his garden.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: This was the first mafioso to violate the Omerta (the vow to keep silence about the existence of the Mafia). He was part of the Genovese family.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joe Valachi

questions.question: Aniello Dellacroce was the underboss of Gambino and so he was the expected successor. Despite that, Gambino chose his brother-in-law for the next Mafia Boss and Dellacroce was given the control over all lucrative activities in Manhattan. What was the name of Gambinos brother-in-law?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Paul Castellano

questions.question: Friends applaud, the comedy is over. were the last words of this 18th century composer.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ludwig van Beethoven

questions.question: These are Winston Churchills last words.

options.text: Now I shall go to sleep. Good night.
My work is done, why wait?

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Everything is so boring.

questions.question: John Gotti has never been imprisoned.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: This serial killer who  believed that his neighbors dog was possessed by ancient demons, told police that the dog had barked orders for him to kill.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: David Berkowitz

questions.question: This is probably one of the most amazing Bosses of the American Mafia. He came to the USA illegally and became Capo di Tutti Capi (Boss of Bosses) after the assassination of Albert Anastasia in 1957. Mario Puzos Godfather is modeled after this mafioso.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Carlo Gambino

questions.question: One of the most bloodthirsty mobsters, Toto Riina, is member of the American Mafia.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Vito Genovese, Joe Adonis, Albert Anastasia and Bugsy Siegel were the four murderers of Joe Masseria. The assassination of this Mafia don put an end to the Castellammarese War.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: He is certainly one of the mobsters that contributed most to the American Mafia. His protege, Al Capone, inherited his criminal empire in Chicago, but this is hardly enough to describe his impact on the Mafia. He suggested the idea of creating the National Crime Syndicate and was nicknamed The Brain.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Torrio

questions.question: I am still alive! are the last words of this Roman emperor.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Caligula

questions.question: He was the most loyal friend of Al Capone. He was Capones treasurer and financial wizard. Because he was incapable of using a gun or killing a person, Al Capone protected him.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jake Gizuk

questions.question: What an irreparable loss! are the last words of Auguste Comte.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Man and Bodies
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, people, country. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: On January 16, 1936 this man who was dubbed the original Hannibal Lecter, died in the electric chair.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Albert Fish

questions.question: This female serial killer has been dubbed the The Damsel of Death for violently killing men along Florida highways while working as a prostitute.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Aileen Wuornos

questions.question: Part of this killers MO (modus operendi) was to send letters to newspapers which were written in code and always signed with the same alias and symbol. Some theorists believe that his cross circle symbol along with certain cryptic codes were indications as to where the next victims would be found.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Zodiac Killer

questions.question: This TV actress seemed short beside her long-time screen partner David Duchovny.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gillian Anderson

questions.question: This famous  American country singer, who is only 5 ft (1,52 m) tall, has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for Recording and owns a theme park.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dolly Parton

questions.question: In November of 1983 Angelo Buono Jr . was sentenced to life in prison. He was convicted of killing nine young women and dumping their bodies in the Los Angeles area. Based on the geographical locations  where the bodies were found, what was the nickname given to Buono?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Hillside Strangler

questions.question: Most likely one of the sickest serial killers of the 20th century, this killer kept his victims decaying bodies in acid vats in his apartment. There were severed heads in his refrigerator and other human body parts around his home.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jeffrey Dahmer

questions.question: Due to inconsistencies in his confession and the wide variety of behavioral patterns regarding the murders of several women in Boston, Massachusetts, there still remains doubt that this man was The Boston Strangler.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Albert De Salvo

questions.question: One of the most prominent painters of the 20th century, this Catalan surrealist who was 1.72 m (5 ft 7-3/4 in) tall, is perhaps best-known for his work  The Persistence of Memory.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Salvador Dalí

questions.question: In Alfred Hitcocks classic thriller Psycho, the main character Norman Bates, was inspired by a real life serial killer.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: One of the shortest men in TV and cinema, this American actor, director, and producer, is probably best known as Louie De Palma from the popular sitcom Taxi.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Danny DeVito

questions.question: This musician, who was only 57 (1,7 m) tall, was lead singer, songwriter, and guitarist of Nirvana and author of songs such as Come as You Are, In Bloom, Lithium, Heart-Shaped Box.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kurt Cobain

questions.question: Being only 54 (1.62 m) tall has not prevented this man from becoming one of the leading US record producers and rappers.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jermaine Dupri

questions.question: What was the name given to the trio of killers who claimed to have had over 110 young male victims in California from the late 1970s to early 1980s?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Freeway Killer

questions.question: This historic person, who was 1.6 m high, had great military and politic achievements as Emperor of the French and King of Italy.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Napoleon I Bonaparte

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: President and U.s. President
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, massachusetts, actor. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who was the last President before the Civil War, also the last president to advocate slavery?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Buchanan

questions.question: Which US General became the Thirty-Fourth US President?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dwight D. Eisenhower

questions.question: What Presidents campaign slogan was The Great Society?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lyndon Baines Johnson

questions.question: What U.S. President served the shortest time in office ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William Henry Harrison

questions.question: What US general became the eighteenth President of the United States?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ulysses S. Grant

questions.question: Born in Brookline, Massachusetts. he was a  Roman Catholic President .
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Fitzgerald  Kennedy

questions.question: This influential musician of the 80s and 90s, who is a little less than 1,6 m (5 ft 3 in) tall, is widely regarded as a music genius. Purple Rain is an album and a song by him, as well as a film he starred in.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Prince

questions.question: What U.S. President was a commanding Union General in the Civil War ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ulysses Simpson Grant

questions.question: This U.S. President and founder of the Democratic Party drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Jefferson

questions.question: What President has an animal named after him, after refusing to shoot one such animal during a hunting party?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Theodore Roosevelt

questions.question: The actor who played Uncle Bill on Family Affair shot himself at 23449 Malibu Colony Road, Malibu after battling emphysema and lung cancer for several months.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Brian Keith

questions.question: What U.S. President led the nation in World War One?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Woodrow Wilson

questions.question: This American actress and singer, who starred in the I Know What You Did Last Summer films as Julie James, is 5 ft 2 in (1, 57 m) tall.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jennifer Love Hewitt

questions.question: Which famous US general was shot by one of his own men at the Battle of Chancellors Ville on May 10, 1863?

options.text: Brig. General Barnard Elliott Bee, Jr.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: General Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson

questions.question: What U.S. President was first to use atomic weapons (1945) ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Harry Truman

quizzes.title: Science Quiz: Guitarist and Slip
quizzes.description: Test your science knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Science, festival, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: He got no respect.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rodney Dangerfield

questions.question: What Whig President, a career soldier, was the second to die in office, in 1850?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Zachary Taylor

questions.question: The Monterey Pop Festival was one of the first big breaks in the U.S. for this guitarist that is ranked # 1 on Rolling Stones 100 Greatest Guitarists. Name this guitarist who had hits such as The Star Spangled Banner  to Bob Dylans All Along the Watchtower.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jimi Hendrix

questions.question: Pleasure in the job puts perfection in the work.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Aristotle

questions.question: A friend is one before whom I may think aloud.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ralph Waldo Emerson

questions.question: What Whig Presidents conciliatory politics helped postpone the Civil War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Millard Fillmore

questions.question: Always forgive your enemies; nothing annoys them so much.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oscar Wilde

questions.question: Its not enough that we do our best; sometimes we have to do whats required.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sir Winston Churchill

questions.question: I think we agree, the past is over.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George W. Bush

questions.question: Assume a virtue, if you have it not.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: William Shakespeare

questions.question: God is dead.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Friedrich Nietzsche

questions.question: How did Les Harvey of Stone the Crows join Club 27?

options.text: After locking himself out of his apartment, he fell to his death trying to climb onto his 4th floor balcony.
He died in a hang glider accident.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was electrocuted on stage

questions.question: A slip of the foot you may soon recover, but a slip of the tongue you may never get over.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Benjamin Franklin

questions.question: Clothes make the man. Naked people have little or no influence on society.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mark Twain

questions.question: As far as the laws of mathematics refer to reality, they are not certain; and as far as they are certain, they do not refer to reality.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Albert Einstein

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Actor and Nickname
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, actor, john. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: I say Pistol, you say ______?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pete Maravich

questions.question: This actress played Ann Darrow in the 1933 production of King Kong.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fay Wray

questions.question: William McKinley was referred to as one of these.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Stocking-footed Orator

questions.question: Theodore Roosevelt was known as the Cyclone Assemblyman, The Hero of San Juan Hill and Roosevelt I.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: This actor, born Arthur Leonard Rosenberg in Tulsa, Oklahoma, was on TV for five years as Felix Unger in The Odd Couple.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tony Randall

questions.question: Gerald Ford was famous for being him.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mr. Nice Guy

questions.question: Andrew Jackson, John Quincy Adams and John F. Kennedy have nicknames in which they are referred to as these.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kings

questions.question: She wrote Mastering the Art of French Cooking in 1961 and had a television program entitled the The French Chef.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Julia Childs

questions.question: I say The Rocket, you say ______?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Roger Clemens

questions.question: One of these pairs (US President - his nickname) is wrong.

options.text: Franklin Pierce - Young Hickory of Granite Hills
James K. Polk - Napoleon of the Stump

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Buchanan - Fifty-cent Jimmy

questions.question: I say The Glide, you say _____?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Clyde Drexler

questions.question: This Oscar-winning actor gave unforgettable performances in On the Waterfront and Streetcar Named Desire.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Marlon Brando

questions.question: I say The Minister of Defense, you say ______?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Reggie White

questions.question: Andrew Johnson was known as three of these alternative names. Which is the odd one?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gentleman Boss

questions.question: He was born in Swiss Cottage, London, England. He won Oscars for supporting actor in Spartacus and Topkapi. His autobiography was entitled Dear Me.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Peter Ustinov

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Woman and Presidents
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, people, professionals. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The most common hostage situation is when the hostage-taker is...?

options.text: Rational and uses people to trade their lives for whatever goal she/he has.
Rational and uses people to attract public attention.
Rational and uses people as human shields so that she/he does not get shot by the police.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Emotionally and/or mentally disturbed.

questions.question: Three of these alternative names belong to US Presidents who have been even presidents (for instance, 12th President, 10th President). Which is the odd one?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Old Buck

questions.question: Calvin Coolidge is known as this Cal.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Silent Cal

questions.question: Who was the first woman to earn a medical degree?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elizabeth Blackwell

questions.question: According to the Bible, Eve was the first woman on Earth.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Martha Washington was the first First Lady of the United States.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: At the scene of any hostage crisis, it is best if the negotiator and the police commander duties are performed by different people.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Who was first lady to win two Nobel Prizes?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Marie Curie

questions.question: Who was the first woman to found a major religion?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mary Eddy

questions.question: Condoleezza Rice is the first woman to serve as U.S. Secretary of State.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: According to the Bible, Eve was the first person on Earth.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Who was the first American woman to reach outer space?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sally Ride

questions.question: Who is the first woman in U.S. history to be Speaker of the House?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nancy Pelosi

questions.question: Who is the first woman to serve as Associate Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sandra Day OConnor

questions.question: Not always are the negotiators professionals. Sometimes they are bystanders who get involved. This happened in 1975, when the terrorist group Japanese Red Army attacked the US Consulate in Kuala Lampur. They made a phone call to notify the US authorities that they had hostages.  The man who answered the phone and became an accidental negotiator was...?

options.text: The consuls child, who was there at that time
A Japanese who was applying for a visa

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A junior embassy officer
